section.text: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Shar Pourreza with Guggenheim Partners. Please proceed with your question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 0, "uuid": "c503bd65-169b-47a0-87ab-a4720c28374a", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hi, Shar.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "8f6a2371-e010-4912-a391-09dd2cb7f8c4", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey, guys. Good morning. Good morning. How are you doing?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "3e06e2c6-2dc1-4b04-899d-359a8b1cace6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: Hey, Shar. Good.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "35dc6cdb-bd83-4798-93a1-2bb5076bea16", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Excellent. So, again, Ralph, as we are kind of getting closer to year-end and we still see continued turbulence in the market, what are some of the moving pieces around offsetting pension headwind? Is it your regulatory filing? Is that enough to cushion some of the drag as we're thinking about '23? And is that kind of a contributing factor for the removal of that 5% to 7% language, which I think caused a lot of investor confusion this morning, even though you just verbally reiterated? Can you just elaborate on this and kind of what you mean by nonlinear for modeling purposes? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "460d7aef-5558-4e6c-92ba-de4574feacfe", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: Sure, Shar. So a couple of things. There's -- if you just look at the pension, there were three factors that we've been looking to offset the pension impacts and the headwinds from the market that you referenced. One, the filing that we made at the BPU, I think we've talked about that being around 20% or so the pension impact. We've got the lift out that Dan has been working on, and I'd say that's in the same 20% to 30% range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "179c824c-a0e3-4a08-b846-c418cd53a60d", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: And then O&M offsets that we've been working on inside the building, which, again, we've talked about for quite some time, we're not going to do anything that's short-sighted, but looking for O&M offsets that we possibly can tab that will stay in place, even post rate case when we make that filing in '23, which will be effective in '25. That -- those three pieces there together are kind of what we are looking at to offset the pension.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "179c824c-a0e3-4a08-b846-c418cd53a60d", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: And then the 5% to 7% specifically addressed that, we -- that we always have said is nonlinear. I think we've talked about that quite a bit on prior calls. So we have a test year in '22 that we're going to be filing in '23 and then we expect rates to be effective in '25. So inherent in that will be an uplift, and kind of drives a little bit of what we talked about as being nonlinear.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "179c824c-a0e3-4a08-b846-c418cd53a60d", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. But just to reiterate, you have not removed the language around 5% to 7%.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "06d01423-e433-413a-9ad9-bfb1aaf8f74d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: We have not. We are committed to the 5% to 7% through '25.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "41f161cd-ab4f-451b-8355-7a247eaaccba", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Perfect. Perfect.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "49012515-c837-4786-ab21-86ef6c84bab4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: Through '25.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "a5bbb5af-328b-4846-8edf-7c303604d0fe", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Great. And then just lastly, I guess, you know Ralph, as we're sort of thinking about your offshore wind segment and sort of the remaining nuclear assets in a sale or retention scenario. We could see some interesting public marks on both fairly soon from some of your Eastern peers. I mean, Ralph, you've been in the helm now for a few months. So you're ready to go. I mean what's your latest thinking here? Are you waiting for public signals to decide what you want to do and where the value is? Is the Analyst Day, the right podium to announce any strategic paths? If any, I guess, how are you sort of thinking about the non-distribution business as you've taken your seat, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "6d08f5c9-dd24-4bcd-be8a-f78d905eaec5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: Yes, so Shar, split those into two pieces, right. First, first of all, wind standpoint we've been pretty uneven. We've mentioned it in my prepared remarks that we are looking at FID on the -- on Ocean Wind 1, that's the project in New Jersey. So one of the things we're looking at there is where the costs come in, and where we finally -- what that project looks like from an investment standpoint, that's pretty straightforward. And then for our Skipjack and other projects, we're certainly looking at what might be out there from a mark, as you said, whether it's from some of our peers, or for some other entity. So there's -- I think the offshore wind is pretty straightforward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "2823b0f9-c152-43cb-803b-194b597f2bb4", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Transmission, obviously, as we talked about, again, very happy to see what the BPU did, might not seem to make a lot of sense when I say that, but the BPU kind of kicking the can and moving. That decision later is the right thing to do from a -- for the ratepayers in New Jersey. There's some uncertainty around the tax treatment of the copper that will be in the water. And so I think what they did there made a ton of sense, and just focus onshore for the time being. So that kind of ties together everything from an offshore standpoint.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "2823b0f9-c152-43cb-803b-194b597f2bb4", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Then from a nuclear standpoint, look, this may not be the most popular. But I think again, you still need more and more time there. There's a lot of details to be worked out in the treasury rates. When those are worked out and we see some marks in the marketplace, we should be in a very good position to tell whether or not as my predecessor Ralph Izzo said multiple times, there's whether or not we're the natural owners.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "2823b0f9-c152-43cb-803b-194b597f2bb4", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. Perfect. Congrats, Ralph on your first earnings call. And we'll see you guys in a couple of weeks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Shar Pourreza", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "f2c6807d-249e-4f6a-b7b8-16889c6b2ee9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Guggenheim Partners"}

section.text: Looking forward to it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "854a4a42-a1ce-4466-b224-3c69fe5bc7ce", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: See you, Shar.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "b15bbb2a-16ad-4b29-8ebf-74fbe4f879d2", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "f2afcaf4-880e-48b2-9ce5-04b2642e9a11", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. Thanks so much for taking my questions. Maybe on the pension first, [Indecipherable] you can clarify or give a little bit more color around the lift-out approach that you mentioned could be pursued for a portion of the pension. And I was just curious if there are any other regulatory approaches that could be pursued as kind of a follow-on to what you've already requested with the BPU?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Arcaro", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "a8707b12-31fa-4a73-9e86-b03b8238d227", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yes, so Dan is going to give you more in a lift-out. Just the other obvious regulatory solution we could is when we file for the rate cases to put in a pension tracker, and at this point, we fully expect to be doing that in our rate filing, but I will give Dan the mic to talk a little more about the lift out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "9f0ea015-1ddb-402a-8415-e5c8ae5f2671", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Yes. And David really there's -- I think the easiest way to think about that is just if the pension is giving us some variability within results, then having it be smaller would give us less variability. And in that same vein, we continue to have a pension that is well-funded. Yet we have seen assets decline as I think every pension fund in the country have, but we've also seen discount rates come down. And as they come down in parallel, the fund stays pretty well funded. But you can do a lift out, which essentially would be taking some of the assets and taking some of the obligations and moving them to an appropriate creditworthy entity and have that be housed elsewhere. And it just essentially would shrink the size of the pension. We are beginning down a path of that exploration. And I think to the extent that we find that to be a successful way to go, we would inform you at that time, but it's also would have the effect of just basically shrinking the overall pension and therefore, the overall variability of it. So I think that's the way to think about it, and we'll continue to keep you posted as we continue to go down that path.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "4030fbe3-0709-4ef8-a881-2b79104f7ae4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay, got it. Great. That's helpful. And then, Ralph, you mentioned a little bit on the offshore wind transmission opportunity, but I was just curious given maybe what you saw with the BPU's decisions and elections within this first solicitation and how the other bidders approached it. Any thoughts on how you might look at future opportunities, whether you still think you can be competitive and how you might respond in terms of setting up other future project designs for solicitations?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Arcaro", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "4f529475-b83d-4f1b-b85c-c27abc38bb94", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Sure. So the selection that the BPU made was, again, focused onshore, right? And I'd like to just think about the state, North, Central, and South, the southern part of New Jersey has a lot of, what I'll call, takeaway capability already on a transmission system because we had Oyster Creek retire and Bill England retire in the southern part of the state. So that onshore transmission system was pretty well set up for -- to take onshore -- offshore generation.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "469dd146-1e12-4fe6-bcd4-67ce4b666196", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: The northern part of the state is also has a pretty robust transmission system because a lot of the work that we've done at PSEG over the past 10 years, 15 years after we started to get approval from projects after the 2003 blackout. So then that kind of left the central part of the state and that project that was approved for JCP&L's Larrabee substation and again, very consistent with the need to have to take more takeaway ability from the Shoreline into New Jersey. So not a lot of learning from that, that was all the information that we had and we would have expected to be in place.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "469dd146-1e12-4fe6-bcd4-67ce4b666196", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: I think what we've all learned, both us and our competitors, is what others are thinking about and how they're both from a financial standpoint, but also from an engineering standpoint, how they were going to design the offshore grid. We think our mesh network is absolutely the most resilient and most robust. We are very proud of that design, keep the lines in and we are very unique in how we did that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "469dd146-1e12-4fe6-bcd4-67ce4b666196", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: And for all 11,000 megawatts, I'm absolutely convinced that you need that robust solution to be in place. So I think we all learn from each other and the next set of bids will be more robust as a result of that. So looking forward to it. But I am confident that our design is a really good design and will meet the reliability and resiliency to state demands.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "469dd146-1e12-4fe6-bcd4-67ce4b666196", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. Appreciate that. Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Arcaro", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "4aaf1ab3-7f6b-4ce6-956e-0ca654e67cc9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Thanks, David.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "6058d757-28ed-4b61-90d7-f13507b4fdbe", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey, good morning, team. Thanks for the time and the opportunity. Hope you guys are well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "94b7ed2e-654f-4525-a0b5-1507e40880de", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Good morning, Julien.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "9476bbf7-9ff1-49ee-8459-7b025e9c80b2", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Looking forward to seeing you guys soon. Hey, thank you. Just following up on Shar's question here, if I can. Just to break down your expectation for an update versus your reaffirmation of the '22 through '25, 5% to 7%, is the -- is what you're prepared to disclose in the coming weeks more around rolling that forward here? Are we talking about keeping '22 as the baseline? I know because of this nonlinearity, I think folks going to be very focused on this piece. Or is this about including the nonutility businesses as well within the EPS guide? Can you give us a little bit more of a flavor of how you're thinking about that relative to what you just reaffirmed on the call here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "613f6438-d4e8-4b81-8c3f-85cdb16f956b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Yes. Well, Julien, I won't front-run what we're going to do in EEI much, but I will tell you that we think about the business is the business we have in front of us at the moment, and we'll look at it from that direction. We'll give you '23 guidance, and then we will extend the guidance beyond that. So that's the way we are thinking about it and the way you should be thinking about it and be prepared for EEI.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "a8d421c6-48d7-40cb-8949-689f99c1860b", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. And just to clarify, would that be based off of '23? And then also, are you assuming 2024 here has the PTC in effect versus the hedge in terms of an uplift?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "fd73c181-b241-4459-97cc-3e0ad2f2bb71", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Well, so think about what you just asked me from a PTC and a hedge standpoint, right, that exactly is the core issue that I was raising earlier, which is treasury regs and how that's going to come out, right? So we will pick one of those and give you some guidance based upon that. And for '22, '23, Julien, you can use '21 as the baseline, right? You have all that data. So whatever CAGR you decide to use going forward, but we will talk to you about '23 and we will talk to you about future years.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "958f019d-41ba-409b-ad04-c9d08742f4cf", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. Okay. But you feel covered off of using baseline of '21 and '22 still?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "c8d6a4e8-33a9-4ef0-9271-8a6617ec68c1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: You can use '20 or go back to '19, I'll go back and however you want to go, Julien.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "d3f46ec6-39f7-47fb-aa58-41b8278ccd38", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: I love it. I love it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "0f4dd96c-3554-4f27-a483-f0c3e0fdb216", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: We will give you the CAGR -- we will give you the CAGR going forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "e87857e5-1964-4c5d-8484-0f40b27b185e", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Wonderful. Thank you, guys very much. See you then. Good luck.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Julien Dumoulin-Smith", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "a27b2e70-611f-472b-9c71-a9d42d72eea9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Hi, Nick.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "6b9a1f2f-0c83-40a1-a869-1e651ecb5aa1", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey. Thanks -- hey, how are you? Thanks so much for taking the questions. I just wanted to ask on the hedges. I think your hedge percentages are unchanged for '24. So I guess my question here is just why not do more? Can you just give us an update on your general hedging strategy for the nuclear assets, please?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nicholas Campanella", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "b465a4f7-fcab-4eac-9142-8ca530d9be1f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yes. And I'm going to ask Dan to give you a little more color on this. But again, I will point everyone back to the regs that are needed out of treasury and some of the guidance there. So there's -- it's a balance as to how we are going to be looking at this both from a PTC standpoint, and frankly, our ZEC process and everything in between. So Dan, if you want to give a little more?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "e97897f7-d1e8-4609-af86-676b800863d9", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Yes. I think, Nick, if you take a look at 2022, 2023, essentially fully hedged for those years and really where there's some open is into those years where the PTC comes about. And so Ralph's exactly right, trying to make sure that we understand the backdrop of the PTC is going to be important. I'd say that by the same token, we have seen some decline in markets in the near-term, but those declines really have been mostly focused on '22 and '23, and we've seen the back end hold up fairly well. So we are, I'd say, within the same ranges that we've provided. It doesn't mean we are in exactly the same place. But I think keeping an eye on what happens down in treasury and as well as keeping an eye on markets is how we are approaching things as we go forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "da8408ff-ef8f-4148-920e-43c8baad6d4c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Thanks a lot. Thanks a lot. So I guess just on the lift out as it pertains to the pension, I think you said potentially can mitigate 20% to 30% of the impact. Is that something that we should have clarity on by year-end? Or is that something that you're continuing to work through maybe it's more of an Analyst Day item? And then just as I think about transacting on that lift out and the overall contribution to EPS, is it a headwind, like i.e., a step-down headwind to the 5 to 7 CAGR? Or is it just one -- more one-time in nature and reduces volatility going forward? Just trying to think through like how a decision like that could impact '23 and '24? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nicholas Campanella", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "a53562ff-58f6-41d3-a008-daa537f4bd4c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yes. So probably somewhere -- I'd say Analyst Day is probably the right approximate time for that. It's going to depend upon how our analysis has gone on for us to give you a little bit more detail about it. And I think that at the highest level, one of the ways to think about what happens from the pension perspective is you determine an estimated return on your assets and you have a discount rate for your liabilities. And those comparisons -- and that gap really determines what you see coming out of it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "4ae651ba-355d-4c79-a355-779481050ecb", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: So if you assume that you're going to earn north of the discount rate than a smaller pension while having less volatility would also have less of a contribution. We would certainly include that in whatever guidance we were to give. But I think as we've seen interest rates come up, we've seen discount rates come up, there's not a whole lot of daylight between those two. So whatever we give you will be based upon our plans at the time and our calculations at the time. And I think it's probably around Analyst Day when we will be able to firm that up for you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "4ae651ba-355d-4c79-a355-779481050ecb", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Yes, that would be my expectation that could be around Analyst Day.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "68bc86a9-03ca-49b4-9111-a03635248c73", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: All right. Thanks so much. Really appreciate it. See you in a few weeks there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Nicholas Campanella", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "3a7cffe9-4da2-410f-a0ad-67279de9239d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "43486ff3-e209-43a7-8c88-4010e05eb213", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey, good morning, team. Thanks for giving me time here. Hey, just on the pension discussion, can you remind us what the regulated versus non-regulated mix of pension is? Is it still around 80% regulated toward pension?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Durgesh Chopra", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "9e2a2ea6-45c4-4261-b146-822f8a5e2630", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: It's closer to 70, Durgesh.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "e538a891-135d-4f76-b40a-35d175f41a1e", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. 70%. And so when we think about the lift out, are we thinking -- I'm just trying to see the 20 -- is it -- could you lift out the regulated portion of the pension too? Or is it just the non-regulated portion? I'm just wondering if there's any state opposition or regulatory opposition to lifting out the regulated portion of the pension?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Durgesh Chopra", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "dc3ff3de-1bb9-4cd8-9eda-45d55c04e44b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Durgesh, I think it would be premature for us to get into that level of detail at this point. So some work to be done. And again, I think our expectation and try to set for you is that we will have those kinds of details at Analyst Day.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "bdb97bdc-5cf3-4a46-b7f7-7bfa84fba2ae", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Understood. Thanks, guys. Appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Durgesh Chopra", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "ab27b8c9-902c-4678-be23-02dc7c7ed42e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Thanks, Durgesh.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "3234dca0-40d6-4533-ba24-8e851a5e88e0", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Tonet", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "7c747bde-a39c-4764-9583-0a799b8ae46d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Good morning, Jeremy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "45ba65da-2f07-4bcf-8792-a39f6037794d", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: How are you?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "e707f192-80f0-4679-b554-832e138a0a29", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Good. Just wanted to start off with offshore wind, if I could here. How do you view offshore risk -- offshore wind risk currently, particularly given some of the high-profile development or other projects that have kind of implied a degradation of returns in this inflationary environment?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Tonet", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "55c4226b-838f-47fe-af9b-aa2404f1bf44", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Jeremy, I think, look, where these projects are no different from some of the other projects that you've been reading about. But we have been steadfast in that front running our partner who has 75% stake in this so, and Orsted had their call coming up in the future, and I will let them talk to that level of the detail. But certainly at a very high-level what you've been seeing with others is consistent with what we've been seeing with our projects here.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "2bab3c9a-837d-40eb-b9de-ba98614056df", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. That makes sense there. And I was just wondering as it relates to power, if you could walk us through the return of your collateral postings on power hedges. And is it kind of fair to think of these financings as the incremental drag in the current environment? And are there any kind of offsets looking versus that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Tonet", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "fd452761-465c-4f3e-9e30-e218bf9a9a8b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Yes, I think -- if you think about our overall hedging picture at our percent hedge, 2022 is mostly behind us, 2023 is where most of the hedges are. So you would see most of that collateral come back as we go through 2023. And so as that cash comes back to us, frankly, there's two ways that it could. You could see market moves, which could move it up or down. But over time, as you deliver on those contracts, you would see that coming back to you. And so frankly, what that's going to do is it's going to lessen the overall cash needs that we have and ultimately reduce some of those borrowings. And so as that cash comes back, you can almost think about it as just taking out those borrowings over time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 60, "uuid": "d47a9c1f-c66e-4741-92e8-2b7af4372ece", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: And if you look at the -- like the second to last paragraph in our release, we've dropped from $2.2 billion to $1.7 billion, and that's exactly a reflection of the moves in the market over that time frame that's listed there since the end of September into the end of October. So Dan's explanation is completely aligned with what we have there in that release.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "feb342ad-a068-4f6e-8bd8-899977346854", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. That's helpful. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jeremy Tonet", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "272a6e98-43af-48ea-8817-541a9deaa84b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Thanks, Jeremy.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "8cd29fab-5d19-431e-8b92-adf6ecadecf7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Yes. Hi, good morning. Thanks and Ralph, congratulations on your first call.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "b35d1ae9-4ac5-4cc9-bc2e-8db60e2066ed", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Thank you, Steve. Good to have you on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "c2fdf621-27bd-4509-a712-e1532dd8a0ba", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: I've been looking forward to this for a long time, yes. So just -- so obviously, you said you're going to give '23 guidance at EEI and then you've reaffirmed the 5% to 7% to '25. Is there -- are you going to give some kind of path of how you go from whatever you give to '23 to get to that end game, 5% to 7% in '25, so we have kind of a view with that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "082fd4e2-1b91-44d6-b7a4-9c68b541013e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yes, we absolutely will.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "4d417a83-7dad-4250-a320-25c1442f7fff", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. That would be very helpful. And then secondly, given the pension impact in '23 as well as the kind of going into the rate case test year, is it fair to assume that you maybe are kind of under-earning in 2023...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "12e8a345-9f63-4e9f-a43b-d446d2fbb7d1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yes, I wouldn't [Speech Overlap]
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "9f19e5a1-c37c-4fc9-8dd9-0b837359bedc", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: [Speech Overlap] as you going with this rate case?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "aae18484-3b5c-4e32-97c8-99f93590ba97", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yes, Steve, I don't usually like to -- if you point to that, but I would not make an assumption one way or the other on that about how we're entering that test year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "bba88c6b-0fc3-4c39-8b24-b0067d324dca", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. Lastly, just on nuclear, Ralph, you've talked about the kind of better visibility of nuclear, but also trying to kind of reduce volatility. Obviously, at the floor price, super visible and a lot of certainty. But at higher prices, in theory, there is great news, great returns, but more variability. Just any thoughts on how that fits into your framework that you've talked about?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 73, "uuid": "b6f13f2c-c38e-4eb3-aa12-462c91c9c5f5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yes. No, 100%. I think, look, a lot of that gets back to the hedging strategy and what makes sense from a treasury rate standpoint. So I think we need to see that visibility, understand what the potential volatility is down the road and then also look at what growth we potentially have from that business and put all three of those pieces together and determine whether or not it fits. And that's -- it's exactly what we've been talking about, and it's not going to happen tomorrow, but we need those regs in place. We need to understand what those growth opportunities are in and we need to see what these marks are.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "9311b19e-aa67-438e-97f6-4416dd10914f", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Growth being stuff like hydrogen, do you mean or something else?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "c5e80dda-bc0f-4bc3-b0c0-7f30c9b4f845", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: You've got -- we've talked a little bit about some growth opportunities that we now have in front of us because the revenue stream is more certain, right? So simple things like fuel cycles. There are a couple of those things that are out there as well that we've mentioned in the past, we would not have pursued based upon a three-year ZEC cycle. But now with a much longer runway out of the PTC, we have those opportunities in front of us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "c2ceeb23-d1e7-4938-8663-928f41cec22b", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Got it. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "7be3df5d-dd66-4d82-a86a-63fe0e691e91", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Yes. So, Steve, I mean, I think implied in your question is you do have that floor, which is helpful from a variability standpoint if you're above it. You're happy to be above it because you had a higher-value location. And then the challenge really just is trying to manage whatever variability does happen there. But frankly, that's a -- it's a better place to be, obviously, if you're above that floor, right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "d5ce77a1-3b65-4e1c-9742-f1a1b26b823a", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Agree. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Steve Fleishman", "section_number": 79, "uuid": "c9a81f95-4cfa-4e5a-8879-52398a011a3c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wolfe Research"}

section.text: Thanks for taking my question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Travis Miller", "section_number": 81, "uuid": "a2f4c38d-b0c7-4b9d-bcb6-25f3f948bcd4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morningstar"}

section.text: Hey, Travis.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 82, "uuid": "6bdff5b0-053a-4824-8fa7-cf80c5621593", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hi. When you think back to the offshore winds discussion, if you weren't to go forward with that or if you were to sell out of that, how do you think about capital allocation over the next 4 to 5 years?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Travis Miller", "section_number": 83, "uuid": "85a03b45-8456-4eb1-a17d-3d06a4b32535", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morningstar"}

section.text: Yes. I think, frankly, Travis, it's -- right now, that is one of the options that's there. I think we've talked a little bit about the other side of offshore wind, which could be some transmission work. And we've referenced that as being somewhere in the $2 billion to $7 billion range for our 50-50 partnership. And so there is still a degree of capital that, I think and as Ralph alluded to before, with the state's target of 11,000 megawatts, we will still continue to look for whether that solution does make some sense. Beyond that, predominantly, capital would be going to the utility part of the business. I think there continues to be areas to invest within the utility, and that would be the number one place where we deploy capital.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 84, "uuid": "ff6e58a7-a10f-4a0a-8aa3-01520df992e7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: And just again, we are still hopeful on that offshore transmission and a full Mesh network. I think there's an opportunity there in addition to the core utility activities. And all of this, though, as we've been kind of teeing up, will come together at the investor conference.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 85, "uuid": "f325b0c5-45c4-4211-b259-d6c24bdc1607", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. And I think you answered my second question, but on your update on the opportunity set in terms of dollars for that transmission, the offshore-related transmission, is that the $2 billion to $7 billion?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Travis Miller", "section_number": 86, "uuid": "2e3ba6e8-0ce8-4a1a-a3ae-8736407bf12b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morningstar"}

section.text: Yes, I mean there's -- yes, again, just based upon the selection that was made by the BPU of just focused on the onshore portions of work that was required that a large part of that opportunity set is still in front of us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 87, "uuid": "748ae07a-7c2c-4725-a60a-0a3ecdc1ee37", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. And so that would be both the onshore and the, say, under the sea [multiple speakers]?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Travis Miller", "section_number": 88, "uuid": "8fedac59-dd3a-4302-a386-4d380da91895", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morningstar"}

section.text: Most of what's needed and most of what we were in our bids were offshore. There's a little piece of onshore that work that could be done up in the northern part of the state, as I kind of laid out earlier kind of think about those three doors or entry points into New Jersey for offshore wind. The largest amount of work that was needed was in the central part of the state, in Jersey Central Power & Light territory, but a little bit for us up in the North, if that entry point is selected.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 89, "uuid": "c22b0c50-3cd9-4ba0-b76f-b540eec30339", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. Perfect. Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Travis Miller", "section_number": 90, "uuid": "2a7ab9f3-3a0c-4659-9d65-6f05822f71c5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morningstar"}

section.text: Thanks, Travis.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 91, "uuid": "0b84b1a2-0716-4913-a65a-37e7c938eb8f", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hey. Good morning, guys.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 93, "uuid": "ba901922-8a52-48db-9380-5a53eda28d6d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: Hey, Paul.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 94, "uuid": "897e8703-5482-4ffe-99ee-6064024234f7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Hi, Paul.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 95, "uuid": "95c1f378-2046-4941-b06e-6dbaa6d2ea6b", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: So just -- I apologize if I missed it, but the BPU order on the pension accounting, when are you expecting them to act on that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 96, "uuid": "f87eb7b0-ece2-4bb6-afea-c6102ff1324b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: Yes. We -- our petition had requested a response by year-end. We have some discoveries and so there's the activity that has gone on, on it, but they will act on their own time. But our request was to see if we could get that in place by year-end. And probably as importantly, to have it be effective year-end. So there's potential if we get something modestly after that, that it could still be effective as of year-end, but that was the anticipation and that's where things stand.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 97, "uuid": "6105057e-36f3-435c-8e99-8ac7c843c285", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. And then on the wind, given what you're saying about the economics and how they might be similar to others, how should we think about FID sort of the steps that we should be looking out for here in terms of the potential for asking for a change in the contract? Or would there actually be rebidding? Or should we think about -- I mean, just sort of how should we think about the timeline associated with your review process and the FID thing, given the changing economics?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 98, "uuid": "128e0075-b9d9-4409-9271-705399fb4276", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: Yes. So, Paul, again, our FID decision is our decision to invest in the joint venture. The joint ventures decision as to whether or not they want to talk to the state or customers, or however they want to do that, that's with the joint venture. And I leave that to our partners Orsted to talk about if they so choose.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 99, "uuid": "33385474-2587-46ed-ad2d-a84ea88b618a", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. But I guess what I'm wondering is, it would seem to me that your decision would be dependent upon the JV's actions and the response to the JV's actions. Do you follow what I'm saying? I thought [multiple speakers].
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 100, "uuid": "53025ba0-84e4-4fc9-9e08-aa8d3d32919c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: [Indecipherable] might be independent, right? And that's the point I wanted to make to you. We could go in either direction.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 101, "uuid": "117acc71-865a-4bc3-bd6c-fed1ea1b77c1", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 102, "uuid": "54b76891-85ab-40e7-80dc-a4a8898042dd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: And they're not dependent upon each other, whether it's changing in the revenue or changes in the expenses. One of those things could impact our decision, but I would also tell you that they may not.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 103, "uuid": "a673c102-0179-40bd-9a4e-7e35a6576f56", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. And then just what's the timing that we should think about with respect to the FID decision?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 104, "uuid": "ecf9b8a2-4fc5-493b-85e5-b2599133c4bd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: Yes, there's no set time and we've talked about that on a number of prior calls. That is a decision that joint venture will make based upon what contracts they choose to enter into and in what timeline. So again, we've left that to the majority owner to speak to. But there is no set timeline in any of our contracts as next date, there will be a decision.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 105, "uuid": "3ede3af9-3891-4622-893e-21591c35b62e", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: It's not a calendar date, Paul. It's just really FID moves you to the construction phase of the project. And so it's when things are ready to move to that phase.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 106, "uuid": "babbfdbb-dfed-42f2-ac31-98ff07ef3fa7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Okay. Fair enough. Thanks so much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Patterson", "section_number": 107, "uuid": "e0657ebd-517f-4967-841b-1dc2d3af642f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Glenrock Associates LLC"}

section.text: Hey, Ryan.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 109, "uuid": "7345463c-7bfb-4eb8-9284-48ac5b9efadb", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Good morning. Hi, everybody and thanks for taking my question. Given the EPS growth guidance through 2025, the new PTC through 2032 and to be made decision around transacting the nuclear decision, how are you thinking about managing the 2025 Power debt maturities to be able to continue your EPS growth rate under the various scenarios?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Levine", "section_number": 110, "uuid": "9a5acad9-fdf3-4667-8d37-a30d433a4199", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Yes. I think, Ryan, it will depend upon overall cash needs and overall revenue picture. I mean we would determine what the best magnitude of debt would be at that entity based upon what that -- the overall economics that can be supported there and what makes sense there. So we don't have an absolute number, but we do have in place is a 3-year term loan that sits at Power and runs to '25 and that's what was put in place after the sale of Fossil. And so as we get a little closer to that date, we will be looking at all that to make that determination.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 111, "uuid": "341cab8a-5802-4039-b6ba-2c82ffff1750", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Is there any consideration to amend and extend the duration to be able to provide more earnings smoothness or keep things more visible?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Levine", "section_number": 112, "uuid": "a0466c09-a2e8-4486-ada0-3843e927307d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: The duration of the debt?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 113, "uuid": "cfa0b2a6-5767-43e3-9cbb-570913657d39", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Levine", "section_number": 114, "uuid": "812d0618-c1db-47dd-b56c-0d95d9428ca9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Yes. We will do what makes sense as we approach that maturity or even before if it makes sense to do it before. But there's -- that will come as we step towards that maturity time frame.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Dan Cregg", "section_number": 115, "uuid": "6a74f62f-a757-46c6-9088-ba9d1e1f1e26", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

section.text: I appreciate it. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ryan Levine", "section_number": 116, "uuid": "4404be0e-91d5-4818-a2b7-831d8e3a4bdb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Okay. Thanks. Well, first of all, thank you for participating in the first call that I've had. I was -- I appreciate the interest and the opportunity to talk to all of you. I also just want to reiterate in this forum, my thanks to our Board and to my predecessor, Ralph Izzo for this opportunity. I am internally grateful and humbled by this -- what's in front of us, but at the same time, excited and look forward to continuing the conversations and providing more clarity and more a little bit about what we are trying to do to remove some of the volatility that has been a concern for some of you at EEI. So I can't wait to have those conversations. And again, I appreciate you all calling in.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ralph LaRossa", "section_number": 118, "uuid": "b2d5bce1-25b4-4437-8cbe-63dbc770f506", "speaker_title": "Chair, President and Chief Executive Officer at Public Service Enterprise Group"}

title: Q&A for PEG (Public Service Enterprise Group) on 10/31/22 11:00 AM ET
